newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Memco targets data security market.
newsitem.headline: Memco targets data security market.

text.p: Israel's Memco Software Ltd is positioning its SeOS software as the industry standard for a specialised segment of the data security market that protects open system servers.
"Our strategic goal is to form partnerships with big companies so that we can achieve our goal to be the industry standard," chairman and chief executive Israel Mazin told Reuters.

The company has signed a series of marketing alliances with leading software companies, most recently IBM subsidiary Tivoli Systems Inc and is armed with $58 million in cash, most of it raised in an initial public offering on October 16.

Mazin said the proceeds would go to setting up new marketing subsidiaries, starting in Europe, and to stepped-up product support and research, most immediately to bring out a Windows NT version by second-quarter 1997. Right now, SeOS runs only on UNIX platforms.
Mazin said Memco would also be looking to acquire other companies with related technology. "But we don't have any plan for any specific technology," he added.

Tel Aviv-based Memco reported on Tuesday third-quarter net income of $0.86 million, or $0.07 a share, compared with a loss of $1.12 million, or $0.09 a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed to $4.20 million from just $0.18 million in third-quarter 1995, the first that the company registered sales.

Memco now sells directly to users, most of them Fortune 100 companies, as well as through strategic partners that embed the software in their own data-security packages. "In the next few years, most of our sales will be indirect," said Mazin.

Mazin said Memco has no direct competition for open system server security, which has helped it to forge alliances so quickly. "The security market is highly fragmented," said marketing vice-president Dorin Miller. "The problems are numerous and so are the solutions."

The market research concern Dataquest estimates the worldwide information security market to be $5 billion, growing to $13 billion in the year 2000. Mazin said it was difficult to estimate the size of the open-server segment alone because it overlapped with others.
